data.title: Past Artistic Directors
data.meta_description: Xavier Brossard-Ménard As both a choir conductor and an accomplished chamber clarinettist, Xavier Brossard-Ménard is passionate about relaying his love of classical music to a wider audience. data.text:
Xavier Brossard-Ménard

As both a choir conductor and an accomplished chamber clarinettist, Xavier Brossard-Ménard is passionate about relaying his love of classical music to a wider audience.

Over the past twelve years, he has directed various well-known ensembles including the Toronto Children’s Chorus, the McGill Conservatory Singers, the Drummondville Symphony Orchestra Chorus, the Université de Montréal’s Faculty of Music Youth Choir, and the Vincent d’Indy School of Music choirs. He was also an artist-in-residence at École F.A.C.E.

His contagious energy, passion for voice, innovative programming, and sense of humour make him a popular conductor amongst both his choristers and the public.

Apart from being Les Muses Chorale’s artistic director, Brossard-Ménard is currently the artistic director of the Joliette Museum of Art’s Choir in Residence and Youth Choir and, since 2015, the Artistic Director of the Saint-Lambert Choral Society. He also directs the Alexandrie Choir, a community ensemble composed of elderly men and women who gather at the heart of the Village in Montreal.

He is the artistic director of the QAT Ensemble, a group dedicated to both contemporary chamber music and the music from the twentieth century, They collaborate with Toronto’s Think Edge Music Collective. QAT has won the LOJIQ-RIDEAU prize to broadcast their work in France and Belgium, and has won the touring prize of the Montreal Arts Council for their performance, 1938.

His work for cinema and theatre includes: recording the music for Micheline Lanctôt’s For the Love of God; he was actor and consultant for Félix-Antoine Boutin’s piece Strip-Tease at Théâtre La Chapelle, he played in François Delisle’s film Chorus and collaborated on Quills for the company Ex Machina,directed by Robert Lepage and Jean-Pierre Cloutier.

Brossard-Ménard has studied at the Université de Montréal, as well as the Conservatories of Milan and Amsterdam. In his spare time, he enjoys learning new languages, tending to his potted plants, discovering new spices to use in his cooking, and studying new musical scores.
